Hilbert spaces and their operators are the basic objects of quantum theory. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Banach spaces. This result is a step toward a reconstruction of quantum mechanics in terms of continuous functions alone. It also has implications for the foundations of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This transition may have been facilitated by the loss of signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for multicellular development. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Less)

The ability of viruses to evade host defense mechanisms is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 uses a viral accessory protein, Orf6, to block nuclear import of the cargo-karyopherin complex. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex that is essential for docking of the cargo-karyopherin complex at the NPC. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 evades the host antiviral response and highlights the importance of Nup98-Rae1 in antiviral defense. Our findings have important implications for the development of antiviral therapies. (Less)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study quantifies the impact of climate change on maize production and trade, and it highlights the vulnerability of the global maize trade system to climate change. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This study also shows that the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases to values much larger than present-day values, and it underscores the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet composition. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest dietary overlap. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of large mammals in ecosystem functioning and biodiversity.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of COVID-19 on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses anticipate difficulties accessing the CARES Act, which may limit the effectiveness of this program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris is mostly concentrated in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres, but the total load is far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar exposure ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We conclude that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result is important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System. It also has implications for the formation of the first stars and the origin of the oldest elements in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproduction is a costly process that is limited by a variety of factors. Here, we show that the most important factor limiting reproductive output is maternal metabolic power. We show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has implications for understanding the evolution of reproduction in mammals and other taxa. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn in the brain. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls vascular function and is the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is a network of cells that communicate with each other to control vascular function. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between endothelial cells. The network is surprisingly small-world, which means that it is both efficient at transmitting information and robust. This is important because the endothelium must be able to respond quickly to changes in the body. The network design is also scale-free, which means that it is not dominated by a few highly connected cells. This is important because it means that the network is robust to the loss of individual cells. The network is also highly synchronizable, which means that it can be easily controlled by a central cell. This is important because it means that the endothelium can be controlled by the nervous system or by drugs.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data is likely to continue for some time. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance systems. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. The COVIDcast API is a valuable resource for researchers and policy makers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The selectivity filter is formed by the transmembrane segments 4 and 5 and is highly conserved among potassium channels. The selectivity filter is also the most structurally conserved part of the channel. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the selectivity filter as a crucial residue for the functional and structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This residue is essential for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This finding is of great interest for the development of new drugs and for the understanding of the physiological role of closed-state inactivation.

The role of the gut microbiome in human health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates host physiology are still being explored. One of the most important roles of the gut microbiome is to maintain homeostasis within the digestive tract. This study provides evidence that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the microbiome. This study also provides a resource of biosynthetic genes and natural products for anaerobic fungi. These findings could lead to the discovery of new natural products that could be used to treat infections caused by anaerobic fungi. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such structures is often limited by the availability of materials and fabrication techniques. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design multifunctional structures with arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformation. The strategy is based on the optimal synthesis of multiple materials into composite structures. The synthesized structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The resulting structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design multifunctional structures for a wide range of applications. It is expected to be a powerful tool for the design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin levels in human blood are controlled by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental time-dependent manner in the erythroid tissues of the fetus and newborn, and in the adult tissues of the elderly. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) mediates developmental silencing of hemoglobin genes in erythroid tissues. This mechanism may be important for the control of hemoglobin levels in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which induces sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We show that SREBP1 mediates ferroptosis resistance through induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which in turn promotes lipid biosynthesis. Finally, we demonstrate that combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis and suggest a strategy for the development of new therapies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that the three major classes of LCCBs activate the store-operated Ca2+ channel (SOCC) in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of the plasma membrane ORAI. Our findings may help to develop new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt declines of early-seral–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess the performance of the design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy can be used to develop new antibiotics to combat antibiotic resistance. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. (Simplified version available at DOI)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks can be large, and the number of trainable parameters is a critical factor in determining the accuracy of the network and the number of parameters that can be trained in a reasonable amount of time. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train than popular existing architectures. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for researchers and practitioners in the field of image processing.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to have negative effects on sleep, but the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device suppresses melatonin and phase-shifts the circadian clock, which may have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1 °C drop in temperature at the end of the last Ice Age. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Less)

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice resulted in lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is complex.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of genes encoding microbial enzymes to trace the evolution of beetles, and found that the origin of beetles coincided with the origin of plant-feeding, and that diversification rates of beetles were high during the Mesozoic, coinciding with the origin of specialized plant-feeding habits. These results suggest that the evolution of specialized plant-feeding habits was a key factor in the diversification of beetles.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Simplified)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased levels of complement component C1q in AD brains. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is more likely to occur than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our study also suggests that the inner core is likely to have formed by the two-step nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase. This scenario may also be applicable to other dense objects in the solar system. (Less)

Marijuana legalization is a current social issue. To understand the effects of chronic marijuana use, we investigated the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). We found that marijuana abusers had reduced brain DA responses to methylphenidate, which was associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining cognitive ability of the human mind. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language predict nearly 100% of the neural and behavioral variance in the comprehension of sentences—a feat that has eluded all previous computational models. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the design of artificial neural networks may provide a promising avenue for future research on language processing in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of machine learning, but rather a consequence of the particular architecture of DL. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks. This result implies that the instability of DL is not a fundamental property of machine learning, but rather a consequence of the particular architecture of DL. We also introduce a new algorithm for training neural networks, which is both fast and stable. This algorithm is a significant step toward the widespread use of neural networks in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper describes a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited as evidence for this phenomenon. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study has since become a canonical example of the phenomenon it purports to study. The flaws are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two species are very similar, but the causes of this similarity are not known. We sequenced the genome of a patient with lepromatous leprosy and compared it with that of a patient with lepromatous leprosy. We also surveyed the distribution of the two species worldwide. Our results suggest that the two species are ancient relatives that have remained remarkably similar for millions of years. (Less)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the entanglement of the ground state and the entanglement of the steady state with the exact solution. We also show that the entanglement dynamics of the steady state is captured by a generalized Gibbs ensemble. This result is obtained by combining integrability with the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the steady state. Our work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems. It also provides a new perspective on the emergence of thermodynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in more than 200 million cases and over 4.3 million deaths worldwide. The development of vaccines is the most effective way to control the pandemic. However, the development of vaccines is a time-consuming process, and the current vaccines are not available for all countries. Therefore, it is important to develop vaccines that can be manufactured quickly and at a large scale. Here, we describe a vaccine that is currently in clinical development and is expected to be available for mass vaccination. This vaccine is expected to be effective in controlling the COVID-19 pandemic. (Less)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which was able to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of larger animals are more likely to be discovered. Here, we show that this bias can lead to an erroneous picture of the evolution of cognitive ability. We use neuron numbers as a more accurate measure of brain size and show that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most striking increases in neuron numbers happened with the evolution of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent scaling of brain neurons in these two endothermic lineages. This study has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies have suggested that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others have suggested that it is an oncoprotein. Here we show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator that promotes tumor cell invasiveness and resistance to apoptosis. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main substrates of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family. ADF/cofilin is involved in many cellular processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF/cofilin action is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We find that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments that are connected to each other, and we propose a mechanochemical mechanism that explains this observation. Our results have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may play a role in the appetite-suppressive effects of the type of carbohydrate consumed. These findings have implications for understanding the role of carbohydrates in the development of obesity and diabetes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found together. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are closely related and that the island was colonized by both populations. We also find that the population structure is not only driven by admixture but also by the geography of the island. This suggests that the colonization of Madagascar was not homogeneous and that the population structure is a result of a combination of processes. Our results provide a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar. They also provide a framework to study the genetic diversity of other islands.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of misinformation, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads mRNA sequences and translates the genetic code into proteins. The ribosome can also modify mRNA sequences, which can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis and the decoding of mRNA codons. Our work suggests that the ribosome can encounter Ψ moieties in mRNA and that the presence of Ψ can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. This study highlights the potential for mRNA modifications to alter the rate of protein synthesis and the decoding of mRNA codons. This work also provides a structural basis for how the presence of Ψ can alter the rate of protein synthesis. (Less)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, educational attainment, and health status. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study examines the drivers of the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals, the most recent group of mammals to invade the water. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the leading cause of the common cold and is the most common cause of respiratory infections in humans. The rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that the rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense and respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to detect the presence of surfaces on short timescales, which in turn promotes long-term attachment to surfaces and the production of virulence factors. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This study provides insights into the evolution of bacterial mechanochemical signaling systems. It also has implications for the development of new strategies to control bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this trend is expected to continue. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. This risk is highest in countries with the weakest environmental regulations. The results of this study highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. This discovery has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings have implications for the management of wildlife and the development of strategies to mitigate the risk of future zoonotic outbreaks. (Less)

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins cause neuronal death are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ and oligomers are toxic to neurons, and that they are the primary cause of the neuroinflammatory response in AD. We also show that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant risk factor for the development of the neuroinflammatory response. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. Here we present evidence that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens comes from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. We argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in great structural detail. We have applied this method to maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway. The intermediate is adjacent to the native state in the sequence of the protein.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap formed by these molecules is not the same as the one used to remove the cap formed by nucleoside triphosphates. This enzyme, which is also responsible for removing the cap formed by the bacterial messenger RNA, has a unique mechanism for recognizing the 5′ termini of capped RNAs. This finding has implications for the regulation of gene expression in response to stress. (Less)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine deprivation is involved in the development of sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation while decreasing the expansion of Treg and MDSCs. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state, in which it is difficult to cause its next state change. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including earthquakes, fire spreading, neural networks, and sandpiles. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and quantum computing. However, it is not easy to control its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This is achieved by strain engineering. Our findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. They also provide a new perspective on the relationship between bandgap and phonon instability in diamond. This work is expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices. (Less)

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of fungi is less clear. Here, we show that a group of plant-specific peptides with antifungal activity can be used as a fungicide. This is the first report of a fungicide that is derived from a plant-specific peptide. This work also illustrates the potential of a structural approach to identify and characterize antifungal peptides. This approach can be applied to other peptide families. This work also illustrates the potential of a structural approach to identify and characterize antifungal peptides. This approach can be applied to other peptide families.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also demonstrate that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Less)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the protein to a second state with faster binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD, and the results are consistent with the hypothesis that VWF is a conformational switch. The results also suggest that the protein may be a useful target for drug development.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied extensively. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, and we find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases. This database will be useful for future studies of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. Our ACI analysis shows increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius—consistent with expectations—but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic compositions of the oceans in the Archean, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for assessing the temperature history inferred from the isotopic record by using the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people each year, and there is no cure for the disease. The parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, but the role of the host cell in the process is largely unknown. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the red blood cell, which may help the parasite to invade the cell. This finding would suggest that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical system, but rather a system that is working in concert with the host cell to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process. (Less)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, sensors, and quantum computing. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. This work shows that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be completely closed, without breaking into pieces. This work also shows that diamond can be demetallized, and the bandgap can be completely opened, without breaking into pieces. This work provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond. This work also provides a new route to tailor the properties of diamond.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza disease is of great interest. In this study, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We also show that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza virus infection and exacerbates disease outcome. Our study provides insights into the role of environmental factors in influenza disease pathogenesis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza vaccine design and therapy. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power. This increase is consistent with the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggests that the brain implements this operation by merging words into phrases. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This hierarchical representation may be essential for the efficient processing of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major pathway in development and homeostasis. It is also a major pathway in cancer. The pathway is activated by extracellular signals and leads to the degradation of β-catenin. The degradation of β-catenin leads to the activation of a number of genes, including the destruction protein, Axin. Axin then inhibits the degradation of β-catenin. We show here that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the canonical Wnt pathway. This is an example of how subtle differences in gene regulation can lead to the regulation of a major pathway in development and cancer.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc). We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, peri-LH neurons, or the VTA. These results suggest that LH neurons may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen fertilizers is one of the main causes of environmental degradation and climate change. The use of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) in agriculture is a promising strategy to reduce the dependence on chemical nitrogen fertilizers and to mitigate the environmental impact of agriculture. However, the use of BNF in agriculture is limited by the lack of efficient strategies to deliver the fixed nitrogen to the plant. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled BNF system in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a step toward the development of a sustainable nitrogen fertilization strategy in agriculture. (Less)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under increasing pressure from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to inform forest monitoring and policy decisions. However, the effectiveness of these alerts in deterring deforestation is unclear. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use sound to perceive the world and communicate with each other. The ability to hear is fundamental to all animals, and the auditory organs of these animals are diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We use a global model to estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 200 million cases and more than 4.5 million deaths worldwide. The need for a global vaccine supply is urgent, and the development of a vaccine based on the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein has been a key strategy. Here we report the design and synthesis of an engineered RBD that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed in bacteria, which will enable large-scale production of a vaccine that can be deployed globally. This approach may be applicable to other vaccine antigens. (Less)

The role of the ALK receptor in development and disease is well established. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and human ALK/LTK are activated by zebrafish and human ALKALs. We further show that loss of ALKAL function leads to iridophore patterning defects in zebrafish and that loss of ALKAL function is lethal in zebrafish. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK/LTK family receptors in neural crest development and suggest a role of ALKALs in this process. Our findings may have implications for the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in human disease.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the pathogen responsible for the Black Death, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The timing of its emergence is still debated, but the available evidence suggests it was a relatively recent event. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative years of its evolution. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not widespread during this period and that it underwent a series of evolutionary steps that led to its emergence. This study provides new insights into the early history of plague and its relationship with its host. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of global food production. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can mitigate these losses and that the fate of SOC is strongly influenced by the management of the crop rotation. These results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial forages into annual cropping systems to mitigate SOC losses and suggest that the management of grasslands can play a key role in climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, to estimate the risk of spillover and spread of wildlife viruses in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment. We also identify the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae as a convergent adaptation to hummingbird pollination. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in plant–pollinator interactions. (Less)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of functional variants in a sample of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our results indicate that women in this population had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some women had artificial skull deformations, which may have been associated with the genetic ancestry they carried. Finally, we found that many functional variants associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in this population. These results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and the processes that shaped modern European genetic structure. (Less)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing countermeasures against future bat coronavirus-mediated outbreaks. The ability to rapidly detect and characterize pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating the spread of emerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based platform to perform unbiased metagenomic sequencing of RNA extracted from serum samples of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates the feasibility of pathogen surveillance using unbiased metagenomic sequencing in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the spread of emerging pathogens. (Less)

The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA polymerases, but these are proteins. Here, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules in the absence of proteins. This polymerase can replicate RNA templates to completion, and can amplify short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately, and the mortality was reduced.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a highly toxic metal that must be tightly regulated. The role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis has been poorly characterized. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a compound that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This work suggests that fungal natural products may play a role in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the maintenance of copper homeostasis in the presence of competing microbes. This work also suggests that the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis may be more widespread than previously appreciated. (Less)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of silica, is a rare event in nature. Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a unique discovery. The tridymite at Marias Pass is well-crystalline and is consistent with high formation temperatures. The sedimentary rock at Marias Pass is cogenetic with the tridymite, and the tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass are detrital. The amorphous silica, mixed-cation salts, and oxides are diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a unique discovery. (Less)

Frost damage is a major threat to plant and animal productivity, and the geographic distribution of frost events is changing in response to climate warming. We use a global dataset of frost events to infer the resistance strategies of woody species and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Our results reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our findings also highlight the importance of studying the evolutionary impact of climate change.

The development of a pathogenic Th17 cell population is a key event in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease pathogenesis may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the only cells in the human body that cannot be replaced. We now report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease and screen for therapeutics. We show that astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. It will also allow us to study the role of astrocytes in ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. This will help us to understand the disease and develop new treatments.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the composition of the tick microbiota. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod vector to enhance transmission of infectious diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major evolutionary lineage that is critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. However, the currently limited known diversity of early branching pygostylians obscures our understanding of this major transition in avian evolution. Here, we describe a basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China that adds important information about early members of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.
