The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without understanding the behavior of the components of the system. In this paper, we show that one of the components of the climate system, the stratospheric water vapor, has a significant effect on the climate. This is important because it means that the climate system is not as simple as some people have thought.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate its identity, warn of danger, or blend in with its surroundings. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is present in many species and has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution. We describe the function of this protein and show that it is responsible for the color of some animals. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of the color of animals. It also provides a tool to study the function of a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the ability of cancer cells to survive in hypoxic environments is critical for the development of cancer. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the initiation of cancer. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

The use of fetal animal skins to make parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a study of 464 parchment samples from 72 pocket Bibles and 293 additional samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, and identified the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This study also demonstrates the utility of a simple and objective method for the identification of animal origin in codicology. (Less)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The extinction occurred between 251.941 and 251.880 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the retinoic acid-related orphan receptor (ROR) family, which is involved in various biological processes, such as cancer and metabolism. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium (IE) remains unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs and that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, such as inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in the spike protein of currently circulating viruses. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent conformational changes required for membrane fusion. This study provides a structural basis for the increased transmissibility of the D614G mutant virus. (Less)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the well-known result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) for finite games. Our result is also a generalization of the result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of infinite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are essential for understanding the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we propose a new way of thinking about chemical properties, which is based on the chemical potential of the electron in an atom. We find that chemical properties, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding the transition metals become electron acceptors, while the elements following them become electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward understanding the chemistry of matter under pressure. It is also a step toward understanding the chemistry of the universe.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon balance of terrestrial ecosystems. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and carbon. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by increasing greenhouse gases. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios, highlighting the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to mitigate the risk of more extreme wildfires.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont that is associated with the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is producing light, and that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is able to use it to maintain its population level and to produce light at night. This glycan-based control of symbiont population levels may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbioses. (Less)

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding human behavior. However, the complexity of text data makes it difficult to identify latent patterns. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to a wide range of domains. We believe that this method will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30–50% of the population of Europe, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the Black Death and its impact on human history. It also provides a method for the reconstruction of past disease outbreaks, which can be applied to other diseases and other time periods. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. The recent mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America is the most extensive outbreak of its kind in the history of this group of animals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with rapid loss of tissue turgor and death. This study provides evidence that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars and that it has been present on the Pacific Coast of North America for at least 72 y. This finding has implications for the management of this important group of animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is urgently needed. Here we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We further show that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that the IL1RAP antibody may be used to treat other diseases in which IL1 signaling is important. This is an important step toward the development of new therapies for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian and Bantu populations are found. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Austronesian and Bantu populations are closely related, and that the Bantu population is also closely related to the population in Southeast Asia. The Austronesian population is more closely related to the population in Eastern Africa than to the Bantu population. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique. We find that the population in Madagascar is a mixture of African and Asian populations, but the mixture happened recently, and the population is still growing. Finally, we find that the population is structured by geography, suggesting that the population has been influenced by local events. These results are important for understanding the settlement history of Madagascar and the diversity of the island. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the genomic consequences of the settlement history.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the protein interferes with the activity of the RNA and base pairing interferes with the protein. This demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This work provides insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria. It also demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of small RNAs compete. This is an example of a mechanism that may be important for the evolution of small RNAs. It also provides a mechanism for the evolution of competing functions for the same RNA. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We propose a method to convert the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable, which is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting probabilistic variable is robust across different crops, exhibits long-term stability, and has nation-wide validity. We demonstrate that the proposed probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. This adaptive change in excitability is a consequence of changes in the strength of synaptic input. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on a simple idea: information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neural populations. This work may have implications for the study of memory in general.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration rates increase with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes has been shaped by the transition of photosynthesis to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings provide a molecular basis for the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle and the molecular mechanisms of the functional reduction of plastid genomes. They also provide a framework for the study of the molecular evolution of other organelles.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was the result of a combination of natural and anthropogenic factors. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study is important for the water security of the world’s largest urban water supply system. It also highlights the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the risk assessment of droughts. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal, in the form of a nuclear test explosion, has the potential to further accelerate the development of this field. Here, we report the discovery of a naturally occurring icosahedral quasicrystal in red trinitite, the glassy material that formed after the first nuclear test explosion. The discovery of this material provides a unique link between the atomic scale and the macroscopic world. It also demonstrates that quasicrystals can be found in nature and that the conditions for their formation are more general than previously thought. This work will help to accelerate the development of the field of quasicrystals research. (Less)

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring, the isocyclic ring, is the most challenging step in this pathway. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, to catalyze this reaction, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria use a diiron protein, AcsF. The latter is a subunit of a larger enzyme, the O2-dependent cyclase. Here, we show that the O2-dependent cyclase is a subunit of AcsF, and that cyanobacterial and betaproteobacterial AcsFs require a subunit, Ycf54, to complement the loss of the O2-dependent cyclase. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a hallmark of multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. We found that ASK1 is required for the development of EAE in microglia/macrophages, but not in astrocytes. ASK1-deficient microglia/macrophages exacerbate the disease in a CCL2-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of cell-type–specific therapies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur when conditions are warm. We also find that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur in conjunction with warm conditions. These results suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a potential target for drug development. It also provides a generalizable approach for identifying the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This approach can be applied to other complex disorders with a multifactorial etiology.

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 that cause Stormorken syndrome, and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that cause a Stormorken-like syndrome. These mutations result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates causes pathology in other neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the role of protein aggregates in disease progression in vivo. The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is increasingly recognized, but the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, which we named Myotis pilosus-specific immunosuppressant (MTX), selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential mechanism for the emergence of zoonotic diseases and the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent future outbreaks. (Show more)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, there are two SHMT isozymes, one in the cytosol and one in the mitochondria. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which are effective in cancer cells. Finally, we show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a lymphoma cell line. This work identifies a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells, which may be exploited for cancer therapy. (Less)

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in motor neurons has been observed in a variety of neurodegenerative diseases. Here, we show that these proteins are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of the three proteins that are mutated in ALS, but rather are supersaturated in motor neurons. This result suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in ALS is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This finding may provide a mechanistic explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in ALS. It also suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies may be a general feature of neurodegenerative diseases. This may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the early evolution of the flowering plants. Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group that is sister to eudicots. This study also raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate highlights the need for effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment in MERS-CoV infection. The data presented here support the use of remdesivir in the context of a MERS clinical trial. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont that is associated with the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided only at night, when the squid is producing light, and that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont only in the vicinity of the symbiont’s habitat. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. This strategy may be particularly important for animals that live nocturnally, when the provision of nutrients may be more difficult. (Less)

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The study also shows that students’ perspectives can be valued while maintaining discipline. This is important because students’ perspectives are often ignored in favor of punitive approaches to discipline. The study has implications for the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavages. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were more infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they had sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S protein cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food system also has a major impact on human health and the environment. The food system can be made more sustainable by increasing the proportion of plant-based meals. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to achieve large-scale behavior change toward more plant-based diets by changing catering practices. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the sustainability of the food system.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of six isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be of interest to a broad audience of scientists interested in cancer biology, cancer drug discovery, and glycobiology.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We also find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect the partisan balance of the electoral college. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is unlikely to affect the outcome of the 2020 presidential election. However, the pandemic is likely to have a lasting impact on the electoral process, and vote-by-mail may be a useful tool for election administrators to consider in the future.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 200 million confirmed cases and over 4.3 million deaths worldwide. The virus has also been shown to cause a wide range of disease severity, from asymptomatic infection to severe acute respiratory syndrome. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is proposed to be involved in immune suppression. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be involved in immune suppression and evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the COVID-19 pandemic. (Less)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of this disease are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1). We also show that the up-regulated expression of CRFR1 and AQP4 in the cortex contributes to the development of cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia and suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of this disease. The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the question of how to properly assess the strength of associations that we find in a dataset. This is a difficult problem because we have “cherry-picked” the associations that we look for. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help to make the problem more accessible to a broad audience.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. Our study provides a useful tool for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular regeneration. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be extended to the generation of vascular ECs from other cell types. This study will contribute to the development of regenerative medicine. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand for the “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has been a major advance in our understanding of the role of RTKs in development and disease. In this study, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that the augmentor ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our findings provide insights into the role of RTKs in development and disease. They also have implications for the development of targeted therapies for cancer and other diseases.

Insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Accumulating evidence indicates that stimulator of interferon genes (STING) plays an important role in regulating insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global STING knockout (STING−/−) and β-cell–specific STING knockout (STING-βKO) mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood. Here, we identified a mechanism that limits the genetic diversity of influenza A viruses. We found that the viral genome is packaged into virions in a sequence-specific manner. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This mechanism might also be important for the evolution of the influenza A virus. Understanding this mechanism might help us to control the evolution of influenza A viruses. (Less)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating the atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. This paper provides a quantitative assessment of the role of human activities in increasing wildfire activity. We show that human-caused wildfires have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and have increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. Actions to reduce the role of human activities in increasing wildfire activity should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The underlying cause of this breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs under climate change.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to form tumors in mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. This approach may be particularly useful for patients who are resistant to chemotherapy. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with a volcanic eruption series that led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This finding is consistent with a mechanism for the onset of deglaciation that is not dependent on the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can be used to link climate change to specific atmospheric processes. It also demonstrates the value of high-resolution chemical analyses of ice cores to understand past climate change. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where food security is low. Our map of estimated catches can be used to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to be sustainable and productive, and where conservation efforts should focus. This information can help to protect the benefits that rivers provide to billions of people.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is instead triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. This form of regeneration is remarkably independent of the MAPK pathway and is instead triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. We also identify a form of regeneration that is triggered by sensory activity and is dependent on the MAPK pathway. These findings provide a unique platform for the discovery of novel factors that regulate the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. They also suggest that the mammalian nervous system may be more plastic than previously thought in its ability to regenerate.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genome integrity. In this study, we use a population of wild flowers to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that recombination initiation in eukaryotes is conserved and ancient. This study provides a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant, which will be useful for understanding the evolution of recombination and the maintenance of genome integrity.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, each with its own characteristic temporal fluctuations in functional MRI signal. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been difficult to interpret because of the large number of networks that have been identified. Here, we used metabolic PET, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total neuronal activity, to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern in Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. This abnormality was reduced in advanced Parkinson’s disease, and time-course comparisons of RSN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for Parkinson’s disease, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. RNA modifications are important for the function of RNAs in cells. In bacteria, the most studied RNA modification is the addition of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to transfer RNAs. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA in eukaryotes. We show that this 5′ modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. We also show that this modification is produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that it may play a role in regulating gene expression. This discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes raises the possibility that this modification could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for understanding the function of this modification in cells.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We examined whether epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-me differences at certain loci associated with glycemia persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective targeted therapies. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms of action of alcohol are complex and involve multiple brain systems. The present study shows that alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it may be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is important for the development of flavor. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of a large number of nitrogenous volatile compounds in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of volatile compounds in tomato fruit and the potential for improving flavor. (Less)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity depends on the thermal tolerance traits of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is more complex than previously assumed, and that the effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be more variable than previously thought.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its activity is essential for learning the locations of objects and scenes in the environment. The organization of neurons in MEC is critical for understanding how the brain represents the location of objects and scenes in space. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in MEC while mice freely explored an open field. We found that grid cells, which are essential for learning the locations of objects and scenes in space, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will be useful for understanding how the brain represents the location of objects and scenes in space. (Less)

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) protein is a flowering signal that is able to induce flowering in a variety of species. We also show that the FT protein is able to induce flowering in a parasitic plant, the dodder. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model system for studying the evolution of flowering regulation. (Less)

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This work provides a unique view of the dopamine-containing nigral system and its connections. It also suggests that the striosome–dendron bouquets are specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. This work may be of interest to researchers in neuroscience, neuroanatomy, neurobiology, and neurochemistry.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have not been well characterized. In this study, we demonstrate that Si priming of plant resistance against insect herbivores involves the promotion of jasmonic acid (JA)-mediated defense responses. Our results suggest that Si priming of plant resistance against insect herbivores involves priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of JA accumulation. These findings provide insights into the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivory. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of lipid metabolism and macrophage activation. These findings may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the design of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and beyond.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient pollution in lakes and rivers. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in nearshore areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries, as they can have a disproportionately large impact on coastal eutrophication. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies, such as the Chesapeake Bay, to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of complex systems that are biased toward rare configurations, such as the dynamics of biological networks, the evolution of social networks, and the dynamics of the Internet.

The mechanisms by which the NMDA-receptor antibody causes paroxysmal EEG abnormalities are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry render the brain susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities when these changes are changed. This suggests that the same circuit changes can be tolerated in the absence of antibody, but that the presence of antibody increases the susceptibility to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the presence of antibody may be a useful biomarker for the prediction of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This may be important for the development of new therapies. The history of Earth’s climate is marked by abrupt warming events. These events are often superimposed on longer-term greenhouse climate states. Here, we present a study of one such event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a global warming and a pronounced negative carbon isotopic excursion. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that can lead to abrupt warming events and the potential for such events to occur in the future.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but only after most forests had been cleared. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In many species, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple alleles, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a single species, finding that the number of sexes is coupled to the number of secondary sexual characteristics. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Less)

The retina is a unique tissue in that it is challenged by two distinct classes of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptor cells and by the pigment epithelium, respectively. The latter is also challenged by the accumulation of lipid-derived reactive oxygen species-generating species that are photogenerated by the pigment epithelium. We sought to understand how the levels of iron (Fe) impact the retina, given that Fe is a key component of both ROS sources. We found that Fe levels impact the retina by influencing the levels of lipid-derived reactive oxygen species-generating species. These findings have implications for the understanding of retinal disease and for the development of therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization has been a central topic in ecology for decades. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to occur throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians, have evolved modularity in their predatory structures, and that these structures have strong evolutionary associations with prey type. Our findings suggest that specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs, and that specialization can be maintained in the face of morphological change. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization has shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the hominin hand fossil record has been hampered by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene to recent period that preserves a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand. The discovery of this fossil also suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study highlights the importance of the study of the hominin fossil record in the early Pleistocene. (Less)

Cancer cells have a high demand for one-carbon units, which are essential for cell growth. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, there are two SHMT isozymes, one in the cytosol and one in the mitochondria. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks tumor growth in a colon cancer xenograft model. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which are effective in cancer cells. Finally, we show that one-carbon donor formate is a potent inhibitor of SHMT, and that DLBCL cells are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, formate is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These studies provide a foundation for the development of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT1/2. Such inhibitors may be useful in cancer therapy. They may also be useful in the treatment of other diseases, such as neurodegenerative disorders.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely appreciated. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new field of research and one that is likely to become increasingly important in the future.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the use of farm machinery increasing food production by a factor of 30 since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
